question: Given that space probes land on planets to collect and analyze samples, and the Viking I Lander did this on Mars, what type of spacecraft was the Viking I Lander?

content.source_1: A space probe is an unmanned robotic spacecraft sent beyond Earth orbit; landers are space probes designed to touch down on other worlds and carry instruments to analyze surface materials and atmospheric gases in situ.
content.source_2: NASA’s 1976 Viking mission delivered Mars landers equipped to collect and analyze soil samples and study the atmosphere at their landing sites.
content.source_3: Any craft that lands on Mars to conduct on-site analyses of soil and air is, by design, a robotic space probe (a lander).
content.source_4: Interplanetary missions in the 1970s were launched atop multistage rockets; the Viking spacecraft departed Earth on Titan IIIE–Centaur launch vehicles.
content.source_5: A rocket is the vehicle used to send spacecraft from Earth toward other planets.
content.source_6: Media reports often describe planetary missions as “sending a rocket to Mars,” emphasizing the launch vehicle rather than the payload.
